answer_html: \(\displaystyle y=-2 + e^{3t} + Ce^{2t}\) completing the question.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle y=-2 + e^{3t} + Ce^{2t}$ completing the question.
hints_html:
Try using an integrating factor.

Try using an integrating factor of \(e^{-2t}\) (so multiply both sides of the equation by this factor). This \(-2\) in the exponent of e comes from the coefficient of the y term in the differential equation.
hints_latex:
Try using an integrating factor of $e^{-2t}$ (so multiply both sides of
the equation by this factor). This $-2$ in the exponent of \emph{e}
comes from the coefficient of the \emph{y} term in the differential
equation.
hints_raw:
Try using an integrating factor.
Try using an integrating factor of <math> e^{-2t} </math> (so multiply both sides of the equation by this factor). This <math>-2 </math> in the exponent of ''e'' comes from the coefficient of the ''y'' term in the differential equation.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
Following the hint, we multiply both sides by the integrating factor \(e^{-2t}\) to get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle e^{-2t}\frac{dy}{dt} - 2ye^{-2t} = 4e^{-2t} + e^{t}\end{aligned}\]

The point of the integrating factor is that we can now express the left hand side as simple derivative:

\[\begin{aligned} e^{-2t}\frac{dy}{dt} - 2ye^{-2t} = \displaystyle (ye^{-2t})'\end{aligned}\]

Plugging this into the initial equation above we find

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (ye^{-2t})' = 4e^{-2t} + e^{t}\end{aligned}\]

and by integrating both sides we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle ye^{-2t} = -2e^{-2t} + e^{t} + C\end{aligned}\]

Solving for y yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y = -2 + e^{3t} + Ce^{2t}\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Following the hint, we multiply both sides by the integrating factor <math> e^{-2t} </math> to get

:<math>
\displaystyle e^{-2t}\frac{dy}{dt} - 2ye^{-2t} = 4e^{-2t} + e^{t}
</math>

The point of the integrating factor is that we can now express the left hand side as simple derivative:

:<math>
e^{-2t}\frac{dy}{dt} - 2ye^{-2t} = \displaystyle (ye^{-2t})'
</math>

Plugging this into the initial equation above we find

:<math>
\displaystyle (ye^{-2t})' = 4e^{-2t} + e^{t}
</math>

and by integrating both sides we obtain

:<math>
\displaystyle ye^{-2t} = -2e^{-2t} + e^{t} + C
</math>

Solving for ''y'' yields

:<math>
\displaystyle y = -2 + e^{3t} + Ce^{2t}
</math>

completing the question.
statement_html:
Solve the differential equation:

\[\begin{aligned} y'-2y=4+e^{3t}\end{aligned}\]

(Give the general solution)
statement_raw:
Solve the differential equation:
:<math> y'-2y=4+e^{3t}</math> 
(''Give the general solution'')
